Introduction

Mitral stenosis results from valve calcification and stiffening that impede valve opening and diastolic blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle.  Most cases are due to rheumatic heart disease (RHD).  Severe mitral stenosis leads to heart failure and also greatly increases the risk of cardiac thromboembolic disease.

Pathophysiology



The pathophysiology of mitral stenosis usually involves chronic inflammation and scarring of the mitral valve leaflets, resulting from repeated episodes of rheumatic fever.  This leads to thickening, calcification, and fusion of the valve leaflets, reducing their mobility and restricting the opening of the mitral valve orifice.  Consequently, blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle is impeded, restricting cardiac output and causing increased pressure in the left atrium and pulmonary circulation.

Etiologies



  • RHD accounts for the vast majority of cases of mitral stenosis.  Most of these cases are seen in patients who spent childhood in medical resourceâ€“limited countries where RHD is endemic (eg, parts of Latin America, Africa, and Southeast Asia).  However, cases are occasionally seen in patients who did not grow up in an endemic area.  A variable latency period (approximately 10-40 years) separates the initial episode of rheumatic fever and mitral stenosis symptom onset.  This period tends to be shorter in regions where RHD is endemic (eg, symptomatic presentation in adolescence) and longer in regions where it is not (age 35-50), perhaps due to more frequent exposure to group A streptococcal antigens in endemic regions.
  • Radiation therapy (eg, for Hodgkin lymphoma) can lead to valvular fibrosis and stiffening and is an occasional cause of mitral stenosis.  When it occurs, the mitral stenosis typically presents 10-20 years following receipt of thoracic radiation therapy.
  • Age-related mitral annular calcification (
    figure 1
    ) is commonly seen in patients age >65; it is accelerated by chronic kidney disease and risk factors for atherosclerosis (eg, hypertension, smoking).  It is usually an incidental finding that does not affect mitral valve function, but it can occasionally cause hemodynamically significant mitral stenosis.

Pathology



Histologically, mitral stenosis is characterized by fibrosis, calcification, and thickening of the mitral valve leaflets.  In rheumatic mitral stenosis, the valve damage and calcification primarily affect the valve commissures, often with partial fusion of the valve leaflets at the commissures.

Clinical presentation

Manifestations



The clinical presentation of mitral stenosis is related to restriction of flow (

figure 2
) across the mitral valve.  Patients can remain asymptomatic for years and typically experience a gradual onset of symptoms as mitral stenosis becomes severe.



  • Heart failure and hemoptysis:  Impaired left ventricular filling leads to left-sided heart failure with dyspnea, fatigue, and orthopnea.  Hemoptysis can result from pulmonary edema or rupture of a pulmonary vein due to increased pulmonary venous pressure (pulmonary apoplexy).  The pulmonary congestion progressively leads to pulmonary hypertension (group 2 pulmonary hypertension) and right ventricular pressure overload (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    ).  Eventually, right-sided heart failure develops with hepatic congestion, ascites, peripheral edema, and elevated jugular venous pressure.


  • Pregnancy:  Mitral stenosis due to RHD is much more common in women (approximately 80% of cases), for unclear reasons.  In addition, the increase in blood volume that occurs with pregnancy is a common precipitant of symptoms in patients with mitral stenosis who were previously asymptomatic.  The stenotic mitral valve is unable to accommodate the increased blood volume and the need for increased cardiac output, causing a rise in left atrial pressure and resulting pulmonary edema.


  • Atrial fibrillation:  Atrial fibrillation is common with mitral stenosis due to elevated left atrial pressure and resulting left atrial enlargement.  It is often the initial presentation in mitral stenosis because the loss of atrial contraction and increased ventricular rate further impairs diastolic filling and can precipitate decompensated heart failure.  Stagnation of blood flow within the left atrium also substantially increases cardiac thromboembolic risk (more so than other causes of atrial fibrillation); systemic embolization (eg, stroke, acute limb ischemia) is sometimes the initial presentation of mitral stenosis.  Prior to the widespread use of preventative anticoagulation, up to 30% of patients with severe mitral stenosis experienced a thromboembolic event at some point in the disease course.

Physical examination



Characteristic physical examination findings in mitral stenosis include:



  • An opening snap followed by a rumbling diastolic murmur (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: video 1
    ) with presystolic accentuation is best heard at the cardiac apex.  The presystolic accentuation is caused by atrial contraction forcing blood through the stenotic valve at the end of diastole; it does not occur in the setting of atrial fibrillation.
  • A normal left ventricular apical impulse is typically present because the left ventricle is unaffected by volume or pressure overload.
  • A soft S1 is usually present due to impaired closure of the stenotic mitral valve.
  • A loud S2 can be present due to pulmonary hypertension causing forceful closure of the pulmonic valve.
  • A right-sided S4 may be present when pulmonary hypertension develops, and a right-sided S3 may be present when right-sided heart failure develops.

ECG



  • Often shows evidence of left atrial enlargement (
    figure 3
    ) and/or right ventricular hypertrophy
  • May show atrial fibrillation

Chest x-ray



  • May show evidence of pulmonary edema
  • May show elevation of the left mainstem bronchus due to left atrial enlargement

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of mitral stenosis should be suspected based on clinical presentation and is confirmed with echocardiography.  Characteristic echocardiography findings include:



  • Elevated transmitral pressure gradient (primary diagnostic finding)
  • Rheumatic mitral valve changes (eg, thickening, calcification, fusion of the valve commissures)
  • Narrowing of the mitral valve orifice (<1.5 cm2 in severe mitral stenosis)
  • Left atrial enlargement without left ventricular hypertrophy or cavity enlargement
  • Right ventricular enlargement with evidence of pulmonary hypertension

Differential diagnosis



  • Mitral regurgitation can also present with pulmonary edema and other signs of heart failure.  However, it is recognized by a holosystolic murmur best heard at the cardiac apex (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: video 2
    ).  In addition, mitral regurgitation causes left ventricular volume overload with compensatory eccentric hypertrophy and associated examination findings (eg, laterally displaced point of maximal impulse, left-sided S3).


  • A left atrial myxoma is a benign neoplasm that can obstruct blood flow through the mitral valve with a presentation similar to that of mitral stenosis.  However, because the mass is typically mobile, the obstructive symptoms are often position dependent (ie, worse when lying on the left side).  Echocardiography reveals the mobile mass in the left atrium.


  • Idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension, like mitral stenosis, can present with signs and symptoms of right-sided heart failure and most commonly affects relatively young women.  However, elevated left atrial pressure and pulmonary edema are not expected with pulmonary arterial hypertension, and the murmur of mitral stenosis is not present.

Management

Asymptomatic or mild-to-moderate mitral stenosis



Patients with mild-to-moderate mitral stenosis or severe mitral stenosis that is not yet causing symptoms require surveillance to monitor for symptom development and periodic echocardiography to evaluate for worsening stenosis.  Those with rheumatic mitral stenosis should receive antibiotic prophylaxis to slow the progression of valvular damage from repeat exposure to group A streptococcal antigens.

Symptomatic, severe mitral stenosis



Once mitral stenosis becomes severe and symptoms develop, medical therapy can be somewhat helpful, but the benefit is limited.



  • Diuretics (eg, furosemide) can help relieve pulmonary edema and volume overload.
  • Negative chronotropic agents (eg, beta blockers) may decrease the transmitral pressure gradient and improve symptoms by slowing heart rate and allowing more time for left ventricular filling.
  • Atrial fibrillation caused by mitral stenosis is typically managed with a rate control strategy.  Because of the substantially elevated thromboembolic risk associated with mitral stenosis, chronic anticoagulation therapy is recommended in all patients with atrial fibrillation due to mitral stenosis (CHA2DS2-VASc scoring is not applicable).  The use of a vitamin K antagonist (eg, warfarin) is preferred over a direct oral anticoagulant (eg, rivaroxaban) due to evidence of superior efficacy in patients with atrial fibrillation due to mitral stenosis.


Definitive management of severe mitral stenosis requires procedural intervention or surgical valve replacement to mechanically relieve the stenosis.



  • Percutaneous balloon mitral commissurotomy (PBMC) is the preferred intervention in most patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis because it is less invasive than surgical valve replacement.  PBMC involves delivering a balloon-tipped catheter to the mitral valve and dilating the balloon within the mitral valve orifice to loosen the stiffened valve leaflets and expand the valve opening.  The procedure carries the risk of causing severe mitral regurgitation, so it is relatively contraindicated in patients with complex valve anatomy or existing mitral regurgitation.
  • Surgical mitral valve repair (commissurotomy) or replacement is preferred in patients with complex valve anatomy that is not amenable to PBMC.  This includes a minority of patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis and most patients with nonrheumatic mitral stenosis.


Indications for mitral valve intervention include:



  • Severe mitral stenosis with the presence of any symptoms
  • Severe mitral stenosis with elevated pulmonary arterial pressure


Severe mitral stenosis is a contraindication to pregnancy because patients commonly develop decompensated heart failure with the 50% increase in blood volume that occurs by the third trimester.  In asymptomatic patients who desire pregnancy, PBMC should be considered prior to conception.

Prognosis



Untreated severe mitral stenosis is uniformly fatal, with death resulting from progressive pulmonary edema and right-sided heart failure or from systemic thromboembolism (eg, stroke).  Patients who undergo timely PBMC or surgical valve surgery often have a favorable prognosis.

Summary



Mitral stenosis is a valvular heart disorder characterized by narrowing of the mitral valve orifice, usually caused by rheumatic fever.  Diagnosis relies on echocardiography, and management includes medical therapy and procedural or surgical intervention as necessary.  Complications such as atrial fibrillation and pulmonary hypertension can impact prognosis, highlighting the importance of timely intervention in affected individuals.
